metadata.title: Sensitivity analyses of the COPD and lung cancer results (detailed results available from authors) Effects of smoking and solid-fuel use on COPD, lung cancer, and tuberculosis in China: a time-based, multiple risk factor, modelling study Articles

abstract.text: To account for the accumulation of risk, we allowed COPD and lung cancer relative risks from the retrospective proportional mortality study to increase to those from the American Cancer Society Cancer Prevention Study, Phase II (CPS-II), which was conducted in primarily life-long smokers. In sensitivity analysis, we allowed relative risks to remain at their 1986-88 levels over the complete analysis period, representing the possibility that smoking may be associated with smaller relative risks in Asian populations than among western cohorts. The benefits of tobacco control in different scenarios, presented in webfigure 6, would be 23-81% smaller for men and 84-94% smaller for women compared to those in webfigure 4 if the relative risks for effects of smoking on COPD and lung cancer do not rise significantly after the peak of the smoking epidemic.

The effect sizes for the primary analyses were from the retrospective proportional mortality study of smoking in China. 1 We used these relative risks because the deaths in the study were from 1986-88, around the peak of the smoking epidemic in China. To estimate the effect of this choice on our results, we repeated the analysis using pooled relative risks from prospective cohort studies in China. The studies used in the meta-analysis are listed in webtable 3, and the pooled estimates are shown in webfigure 7. In addition to pooled relative risks, we also estimated the pooled mid-year of study follow-ups to account for accumulation of risk. The pooled relative risks were not statistically significantly different from those of the retrospective proportional mortality study of smoking. When we repeated the analyses with pooled relative risks, the results for the number of cumulative averted deaths under different scenarios differed from those in figure 2 of the main paper by less than 2·5% for male COPD and lung cancer, and by less than 2% for female COPD and lung cancer. The difference with those of scenarios in webfigure 4 (ie, the effects of smoking scenarios) was less than 3·5% for male COPD and lung cancer, and less than 7% for female COPD and lung cancer.

About 61% of China's population lives in rural areas, but this proportion is expected to decline to 38% by 2033. 2 Because risk factor exposure and disease-specific death rates may be different between rural and urban areas, we repeated the analysis stratified on place of residence, accounting for the change in proportion of population in urban areas over time. Fuel use by rural-urban place of residence was from the 2000 national census and smoking prevalence by rural-urban place of residence from the 2003 National Health Service Survey, both described in webappendix 1. We divided current and projected age-specific lung cancer and COPD deaths into those that occur in rural and urban populations, using the current or projected proportion of population in each group from the national census and the Population Division of the Department of Economic and Social Affairs of the UN Secretariat 2 and the ratios of age-specific and cause-specific death rates from the "Geographic study of mortality, biochemistry, diet and lifestyle in rural China". We also used relative risk for the effects of smoking on COPD and lung cancer by place of residence from the retrospective proportional mortality study, 1 to account for potential differences in factors like intensity and duration of smoking.

When we repeated the analyses stratified on ruralurban place of residence, the results for the number of cumulative averted deaths under different scenarios differed from those in figure 2 of the main paper by less than 11% for male COPD and lung cancer, and by less than 9% for female COPD and lung cancer. The stratified analysis showed that, due to different death rates and distribution of population in rural and urban areas (including urbanisation trend), for men 32% of cumulative lung cancer deaths and 57% of cumulative COPD deaths over the analysis period were in the rural populations; for women 29% of cumulative lung cancer deaths and 59% of cumulative COPD deaths were in rural populations. The stratified analysis also showed that 54-59% of cumulative averted male COPD and 29-32% of cumulative averted male lung cancer deaths in different scenarios were in rural populations; 56-67% of cumulative averted female COPD and 26-29% of averted cumulative female lung cancer deaths were in rural populations (see webtable 4 for detailed results by disease and by scenario in ruralurban stratified analysis).

body_text.text: To estimate the number of smoking and COPD deaths attributable to passive smoking, we first estimated the prevalence of passive smoking as a proportion of nonsmokers using data from the 2002 National Tobacco Prevalence Survey. 3 Relative risks for the effects of passive smoking on lung cancer (1·73; 95% CI 1·46-2·04) were from the meta-analysis of studies in China 4 and on COPD (1·48; 1·18-1·85) from the only available Chinese study. 5 We divided total lung cancer and COPD deaths into those Effects of smoking and solid-fuel use on COPD, lung cancer, and tuberculosis in China: a time-based, multiple risk factor, modelling study that occur among smokers and among non-smokers (because only the latter are affected by passive smoking). Similar to a previous analysis of passive smoking, 6 the number of deaths among non-smokers was calculated by first estimating the numbers of lung cancer or COPD deaths not attributable to smoking (the total lung cancer or COPD deaths minus those attributable to smoking), and then dividing the non-attributable deaths into those that occur among smokers and non-smokers proportional to the prevalence of smoking from the 2003 NHSS.
